dc:title: Genetic differentiation in two members of the Drosophila athabasca complex

dc:title: Primate skeletal allometry and hominoid evolution
dc:creator: Corruccini R.S.
dc:description: One hypothesis explains the derived body proportion pattern of living hominoids as an inevitable outcome of parallel acquisition of increased body size in the great apes and man. A multivariate allometric analysis of skeletal proportions within New World monkeys, Old World monkeys and prosimians does indicate some tendency for the larger members to exhibit growth patterns that converge on hominoid characteristics. However, these interspecific allometries are too weakly manifested to serve as an adequate explanation for shared hominoid differences from monkeys. This fact increases the probability that hominoid proportions are synapomorphies reflecting a common ancestor that was fully specialized rather than generalized.
